abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Financial Sector
            Technical Assistance Project for Mexico was satisfactory
            with highly likely sustainability, high institutional
            development impact, and satisfactory performances by both
            the Bank and the Borrower. A supplemental loan was approved
            in June 1995 which enhanced project activities including
            additional activities of diagnostic studies of troubled
            banks, hiring advisors for the restructuring of troubled
            banks, identification and measurement of fiscal cost, as
            well as establishing a regulatory framework for private
            investment management of SAR accounts and voluntary
            occupation plans. Lessons learned include: a high degree of
            government commitment is essential for successful
            implementation; well defined project objectives must
            accurately assess the countries needs and absorptive
            capacity; regular monitoring and supervision executed
            directly from the field offers support and allows closer
            contact with clients. Reform of financial sectors will
            require a long-term commitment and the Bank's key role
            and comparative advantage is to stay as a policy advisor for
            the long term.
